member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Communications.IReadyIndicator
member.summary: Interface to be implemented by a device which indicates when it is "ready" to accept commands. This is not necessarily the same as an "online" flag. The device may be online, but not "ready" yet.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Communications.IReadyIndicator.IsReady
member.summary:
True when the device is ready to receive commands and return current information via any property getters or methods with return values, as well as raise (feedback) events (if supported).
When this is false, it typically means the device is either offline or just not ready to communicate yet (i.e. online, but still loading).
Unless otherwise noted in a specific device capability property, method or event, all interactions with the device will not be available or valid until this property turns true.
If an error can occur that will prevent the device from ever being ready, the capability should be implemented in order to raise the error.
Any error raised while this ready flag is false means that the device will never be ready until the error is resolved.
The device may also become ready, but have its property already set. This means the device is functional, but has errors that may prevent it from functioning properly.
All other errors will be raised after the device is ready. If the device stays ready, it means the device is functional, but has errors that may prevent it from functioning properly. If the device changes to not ready, it means the error is causing the device to be non-functional.

member.name: E:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Communications.IReadyIndicator.IsReadyChanged
member.summary: Raised when the property has changed.

member.summary:
Indicates only the default events, properties, and methods on the interface are supported.
There are no required members for this capability. However, a device should at least support one of the available features. Otherwise, it should not implement this capability. That said, applications must expect to see some devices with no supported features since a driver might support multiple device models and not know which features are available until after connecting.

member.summary: Provides control and status for conference calls

member.summary: Options that may be passed to

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IConferenceCallControls.IsCallActive
member.summary:
Whether or not there is a currently "active" call
The call is considered active even if in a paused or transitioning state. For example, it is active even if dialing, on hold, or in the process of disconnecting or reconnecting.
Other properties describing more detailed status may be defined in the future, but when they are, they should entirely encompass the state and not require reading this one to know the full state.
Drivers which might support reporting a more detailed status in the future should still implement this property as it is a convenient mechanism for applications and user-defined programming to use as a trigger for other actions.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IConferenceCallControls.IsSharingContent
member.summary:
Whether or not content is being shared from this device
This does not indicate whether or not another participant is sharing content on the call. This only applies to whether or not content is being shared from this device.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IConferenceCallControls.MaxSharedSources
member.summary: Specifies how many sources may be passed to the command

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IDeviceCustomUi.UploadUiDefinition(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Uploads a user interface definition string to the device
The format of this definition is device-specific, and building up this string is outside the scope of this capability. Often this string is exported from a UI design tool of some kind.
If the UI definition already exists, it will be overwritten.
member.param: Contents of the user interface definition in the device-specific format

The ID associated with this definition
Some devices may support multiple definitions, keyed by IDs. If the driver does not support multiple IDs, it may ignore this parameter. Applications should check whether the driver supports this before attempting to use it.
If the application does not specify an ID, the driver should choose a default one to use. Applications should not call this with and without IDs as that may lead to a collision with the driver's default ID.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IDeviceWithExternalMediaSources
member.summary:
Describes the ability to register external sources on a device that can be selected
When an external source is selected, the device will activate the corresponding physical source on the device and raise the event. The application would then be expected to take whatever actions are necessary to route that external source to the physical connector. This allows expanding the device's inputs using an external switching device.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Conferencing.IDeviceWithExternalMediaSources.AddExternalSource(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Registers a new external source on the device
When the user selects this source using the device's controls, the event will be raised.
member.param: Unique (among external sources) identifier for this source

User-friendly name for the source
The device's interface will usually present this name as the label when selecting the source.

Sets the icon which is associated with the source.
This parameter is optional and may not be supported by all devices. The icon options are listed under the property. Drivers which do not support this parameter may set it to a null or empty value. Drivers which do support this parameter must still tolerate the application providing a null or empty value.

Sets whether the source defaults to available or not
This parameter is optional and may not be supported by all devices. When supported, the state can be changed by the command. This parameter simply provides a way to set the initial value since the application cannot assume the default value is available or unavailable.
Drivers which do not support this parameter may safely ignore it. When this parameter is null or empty, the source will be available by default.

Which connector this external source will be routed to by the application
Devices which do not have multiple connectors may ignore this parameter. If the application passes null or empty, the driver must choose a reasonable default and should specify what that is in the associated driver documentation.
However, applications should always specify this parameter when possible to provide the best user experience.

member.param: Identifier of the external source that is now active

Devices which support this mechanism provide some feedback to the user such as disabling or hiding the button to select this source while it is unavailable.
Applications should assume nothing about the default state of the availability. After registering the source, they should set this status to ensure that the source is selectable (or not) as desired.
member.param: Identifier of the source to set the status of
Whether or not the source is presently available

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device which reports statistics about its computational and related resources
While this interface does have a collection of temperatures, these are specifically intended to be (likely internal) component temperatures. DO NOT use this interface to describe a generic ambient temperature sensor unrelated to a computational device. Other capability interfaces will cover an ambient sensor device. That said, if the device does report "case temperature" or "ambient temperature" among its own operating temperatures, it is acceptable to include that here. Think of this interface like the statistics you might see a computer report in a detailed status window.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.ComponentTemperature
member.summary:
Collection of component temperatures
Keys are unique IDs that are consistent upon reload of the driver. They do not need to be user-friendly and are not intended for display to an end-user. Use the for that.
When possible, drivers should report all known components in this property even when their temperature is unknown. That way applications may choose to list them and indicate to their users that their temperatures are unavailable.
The number of temperatures may vary by device, and in some cases, at runtime based on what is connected to the system. The driver may add temperatures upon discovering their presence. Once added to the collection, though, the driver must not remove a component unless it desires to indicate explicitly to the application that the component has been removed.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.CpuUsagePercent
member.summary:
Overall CPU usage as a percentage
This interface does not currently describe the details of per-core, per-processor, or per-component CPU usage. If the device reports such fine-grained detail and it is not immediately obvious which value this should be, do not implement this property.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.FanStatus
member.summary:
Collection of cooling fans and their status.
Keys are unique IDs that are consistent upon reload of the driver. They do not need to be user-friendly and are not intended for display to an end-user. Use the for that.
When possible, drivers should report all known fans in this property even when their status is unknown. That way applications may choose to list them and indicate to their users that their status is unavailable.
The number of fans may vary by device, and in some cases, at runtime based on what is connected to the system. The driver may add fans upon discovering their presence. Once added to the collection, though, the driver must not remove a fan unless it desires to indicate explicitly to the application that the fan has been removed.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.RamUsagePercent
member.summary:
Overall RAM usage of the device as a percentage
This interface does not currently describe additional memory banks. If the device has multiple memory banks and it's not immediately clear which value this applies to, do not implement this propetry.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.SupportedFeatures
member.summary: Indicates which optional features are supported by this device

member.name: E:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IComputePlatformDiagnostics.ValuesUpdated
member.summary:
Raised when the properties on this interface have been updated.
Because the values on this interface are in reality continuously changing, the values reported here tend to update based on a sampling interval rather than physical state changes.
Where applicable, drivers should raise this event when the full set of values has been updated rather than after each individual value is updated.
This event is provided to let the application know that an updated set of values has been populated. The values may not have changed, but the application may be interested in knowing that the values were sampled and known to be valid again at this new point in time for data logging purposes.
That said, there is not currently a mechanism to atomically retrieve a full "record" of diagnostic values, so the properties on this interface may change asynchronously from this event. If that becomes an important requirement, a new interface should be developed which adds the complexity required to achieve that.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SerialNumber
member.summary:
The device's serial number
If the device is comprised of multiple components with multiple serial numbers, the "primary" device serial number should be reported here. If the meaning of "primary" serial number is ambiguous, do not implement this property.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SupportsSerialNumber
member.summary: Whether or not is supported

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SupportsSystemComponentVersions
member.summary: Whether or not is supported

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SystemComponentVersions
member.summary:
Collection of versions for the various system components The keys of this collection must be user-friendly identifiers for what version this is. They typically match strings displayed on the device's interface and/or manual.
is used for the device's "primary" firmware version. That property should be used when there is an obvious corresponding value on the device. This property must not include the version from as that may cause applications to report the version twice.
Applications should not assume versions will not be added or removed, even at runtime. A device update may cause it to add, remove, or rename component versions.

member.name: E:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SerialNumberChanged
member.summary: Raised when the property has changed
member.para: In practice, serial numbers do not change. This event is provided anyway since from the driver's perspective, it is simply another string that the device reports. A device firmware update may decide to capitalize its serial number, or perhaps the serial number is not available immediately and the driver needs to raise this event when it becomes available.

member.name: E:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.IDeviceDiagnostics2.SystemComponentVersionsChanged
member.summary: Raised when the property has changed
member.para: Because versions should not change often, this event does not provide details about which version(s) changed or whether a version was added or removed.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Diagnostics.SystemCoolingFanStatus.SpeedPercent
member.summary:
The speed of the fan as a percentage of its maximum setting
May be null if is currently unknown. For a particular device, this may always be null if it does not report fan status as a percentage. However, it might also be null because it is not available yet. Applications must not assume anything about whether this will be null in the future based on a previous value. This may transition from null to known, known to null, or never transition at all.

However, it might also be null because it is not available yet. Applications must not assume anything about whether this will be null in the future based on a previous value. This may transition from null to known, known to null, or never transition at all.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Errors.DeviceErrorCode
member.summary:
Defines a device error code. These are unique per device only. Comparing error codes from different devices may yield incorrect results.
For an error code indicating success, use the static instance returned by the property .
Different device implementations may derive this class to create their own error code types. These specific error code types may be consumed by a user interface that is aware of that specific device model and its types of errors.

member.summary:
Index of the or .
For added/current item events, this is then current index of the item. For removed item events, this is the index from which the item was removed. For replace events, this is the index of the item being replaced (and therefore the incoming item, too). For reset events, this will be -1.

member.name: F:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Events.CollectionChangedAction.Removed
member.summary:
An item was removed from a collection.
NOTE: During this "Removed" changed action, the item being removed may not be fully functional. However, it will be identifiable. For example, if it has an ID or a Name property, they will still be valid, but a method such as SetValue() or a property such as CurrentValue will not be valid and may even cause an error if called/accessed during this "Removed" action.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.EthernetPhysicalProperties
member.summary:
Immutable data structure for the configuration and status of an Ethernet port. This data structure may be used in both configuration and status contexts.
When used for configuration and is true, the values of and do not matter and can be left as defaults because auto-negotiation will control these values. This is true for both reading and writing configuration.
When used for status, and must be populated accurately even when is true since in that case, the entire purpose is to report the results of auto-negotiation.

member.summary: Initialize with all required properties

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.EthernetPhysicalProperties.DuplexMode
member.summary:
The duplex mode on the port (full-duplex or half-duplex)
When used in a configuration, can be used when is true. When used as status, should be avoided and the present state ( or ) should be used if possible. However, some devices may not report this when auto-negotiation is enabled and will be reported.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkAdapterInformation
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device which reports static information about its network adapters
The scope of this interface is limited to the presence and descriptions of adapters in the system. It does NOT include any status such as connection state, IP address, or other related properties.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkAdapterInformation.NetworkAdapters
member.summary:
Collection of network adapters on the device
Keys are unique IDs that are consistent upon reload of the driver. They do not need to be user-friendly and are not intended for display to an end-user. Use the for that.
Applications must not assume adapters will not be added or removed at any time, or that a given adapter will not have information change. The only assumption that can be made is that the dictionary key for an adapter will not change, and that a new key means a new adapter.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkPortContainer
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device which contains network ports which implement the capability (via , not necessarily implementing the interface directly on the instance returned in the collection).
See the documentation for for important details on the implementation of this interface.
A power over ethernet port may also implement and be listed in . A device which contains these MUST implement both AND and include the port in both the and collections.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkPortContainer.Ports
member.summary:
Collection of all network ports on the device
If the device implements , this collection (like other capabilities' properties) should not be read yet. While is true, this collection's contents must be populated and may not change. Applications should re-read this collection if the device becomes not ready and then ready again in case this collection has changed. If the driver does not implement , then the collection must be populated upon driver initialization.
Devices in this collection must all include the capability and have unique, persistent s. Note that these numbers do not necessarily match the order of the ports returned in the collection and are not necessarily contiguous.
See for important details on the implementation and consumption of these ports.
Applications MUST NOT CAST the instances in this collection to . The MUST ALWAYS go through . This is emphasized because a common implementation of the capability may be to implement the interface on the instance, so casting might sometimes work and mask the error in the application if it is not tested with a different driver.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkPortContainerItem
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device to indicate that it is a network port (like an Ethernet port, but not necessarily an RJ45 port since this also includes SFP connectors, optical connections, and potentially even virtual ports).
This capability is not implemented on a top-level device and is instead implemented on an inside which also implements the capability to describe the port. A top-device which is only a network port does not really make any sense.
If the device only contains one network port, it should still implement to hold that port rather than attempting to implement and on the top-level device.
The sole purpose of this interface is to identify that this device is a network port and to report the that uniquely identifies it inside the containing device. This identifier must also be persistent across reloads of the driver such that port 123 is still the same port 123 even after a reboot.
This interface is REQUIRED for network port devices even if they do not use numeric labels and the driver author must create their own scheme which satisfies the uniqueness and persistence requirements.
Note that s are not necessarily contiguous and may take any value. A containing may contain ports in any order and is not required to sort by .
A power over ethernet port may also implement and be listed in . A device which contains these MUST implement both AND and include the port in both the and collections. PoE ports can be identified by attempting to cast the CONTAINING the capability (NOT the capability itself) as (which is not itself a capability). Note that the in this case MIGHT NOT match the depending on the device. Alternatively, given an , the application can check if the bank implements the via a call to .
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkPortContainerItem.NetworkPortNumber
member.summary:
The number associated with this port, unique among the containing device (if applicable), but not necessarily contiguous. In other words, it is legal for the of a device's contained instances to be 100, 232, and 779298 (although that would not make much sense). Zero is a valid port number as well.
This number must be unique in the container and must be consistent across a reload of the driver in order for the application to code against it across reboots.
This typically corresponds to a label on the device, or at least a numerical index into a row of ports. If that does not apply, the driver author must make up their own numbering scheme that satisfies the uniqueness and persistence requirements. That said, the number may still be shown to a user and care should be taken to make it sensible.
Applications should expect to be able to present this number to a user and expect that the user not be confused as to what it means. However, the and capabilities should also be considered to help provide additional context to the user.
If this port is also an , the DOES NOT necessarily match this number.

member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a controllable network port device
This capability is not implemented on a top-level device and is instead implemented on an inside which also implements the capability to describe the port. A top-device which is only a network port does not really make any sense.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.INetworkPortStatus.PhysicalStatus
member.summary:
Reports the currently active physical link settings in use on the port as a result of auto-negotiation or manual configuration.
This is NOT the active setting. This IS the result of the active setting and/or the connected device. When auto-negotiation is enabled on the port, this reports the result of that auto-negotiation. When auto-negotiation is disabled on the port, this will report what manual configuration is active.
Note that a driver which only supports reporting whether or not auto-negotiation is enabled on a port may always set to and to 0.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.NetworkAdapterInfo
member.summary:
Immutable data structure describing static information about a network adapter.
This class tells you about the adapter but should NOT be expanded to tell you the adapter state. The properties of this class should not describe things that commonly change on an adapter, such as the connection state, IP address, etc.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.NetworkAdapterInfo.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initialize with all required properties

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.NetworkAdapterInfo.Label
member.summary:
User-friendly label identifying which network adapter this is
Should match the label on the device's user interface or a printed label if there is one.
MUST NOT be null so that applications have something to display. Driver authors can make up their own description here if needed. If you must make up a name, the following suggestions can be used if applicable in order to improve consistency among drivers: "Ethernet" "Wi-Fi" "USB" "Control Subnet" "Network Adapter"

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.NetworkAdapterInfo.InternalName
member.summary:
The identifying name of the adapter as reported by the device, i.e. eth0
This is NOT a user-friendly name. Use for that. This is the technical identifier that uniquely identifies the adapter.
MUST be null if unavailable. Driver authors SHALL NOT make up their own value for this if one is not reported by the device.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.Networking.NetworkAdapterInfo.MacAddress
member.summary:
The MAC Address of the network adapter in "AA:22:CC:44:EE:FF" format
Drivers should report null if unknown. Applications must tolerate null or empty strings for unknown values.
Drivers should use all-caps values delimited by ':' characters with no leading or trailing whitespace. Applications should plan to normalize this string in case of driver author error and should not rely on the string being capitalized.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPingDeviceMonitoring
member.summary: This capability monitors the online status of a device by sending pings to the host. If the device does not respond to the pings then it will be considered offline and will be rebooted in an attempt to get it to reconnect.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPingDeviceMonitoring.SupportedFeatures
member.summary: Indicates which features are supported by this capability.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPingDeviceMonitoring.DeviceMonitoringEnabled
member.summary:
Reports the status of the device monitoring capability and allows for enabling/disabling device monitoring.
True indicates that device monitoring is enabled and therefore will periodically send pings to monitor the online status of the device. If the device stops responding it will be rebooted up to the number of times specified by in an attempt to get the device to reconnect.
False indicates that device monitoring is disabled.
See for the list of devices currently being monitored and use to update this list. The indicates how the online status of the devices in are used when determining whether or not a device should be rebooted. See for more information on the different modes.
Triggers the event.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPingDeviceMonitoring.EnableDeviceMonitoring
member.summary: Enable device monitoring. When device monitoring is enabled the online status of the targets in will be monitored and rebooted if necessary.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPingDeviceMonitoring.DisableDeviceMonitoring
member.summary: Disable device monitoring. When device monitoring is disabled the online status of the targets in will no longer be monitored.

member.summary: Event that is raised when changes.

A list of targets to be monitored. The target may be an IP address, hostname, or some other form of web address. The format of the addresses are specific to the device and may differ across manufacturers.
The number of targets in this list must not exceed but may contain less.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank
member.summary:
An represents one or more outlets that all work in unison, known as a power bank. inherits from so that each power bank can specify the capabilities that it supports.
NOTE: An is not a stand-alone device, it is a component that belongs to an . Even if you have a device that only contains 1 power bank such as a smart plug, it must still implement and then return 1 power bank from .

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.SupportedFeatures
member.summary: Indicates which features are supported by this capability.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.Number
member.summary:
The number used to identify the power bank and to indicate where this power bank is located in relation to other power banks.
The number must be available upon construction, unique, and must not change at runtime.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.Label
member.summary:
The physical label of the power bank on the device.
This should typically match the label that is physically printed on the device (ie. "Outlet 1" or "Bank A"). This value is intended to be displayed to the end user.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.Name
member.summary:
The name of the power bank.
The name is the user friendly way of identifying the usage of the power bank and is customizable by the user. This differs from the which is physically printed on the device and can't change. For example, the label of a power bank might be "Outlet 1" but the user named the outlet "Family Room TV" since that is the device that is plugged into the outlet.
This feature should only be supported if the device itself supports power bank naming. This is intended to make it easier to identify what the power bank is connected to when viewing the web ui of the PDU.
Triggers the event.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.SetName(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the of the power bank.

member.summary: Event that is raised when the of the power bank changes.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBank.NumberOfLoads
member.summary: The number of loads that this power bank supports. A load is typically and outlet but can also be a metering device such as an ammeter. For example, if this power bank controls two outlets in unison then the number of loads would be 2.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBankContainer
member.summary: is a capability to be implemented by a device that contains one or more power banks such as a PDU or UPS. Each power bank on the device is represented as an and can specify its own capabilities independently.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBankContainer.SupportedFeatures
member.summary: Indicates which features are supported by this capability.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerBankContainer.GetPowerBanks
member.summary:
Retrieves a list of power banks, each having its own capabilities.
A "power bank" may refer to a single outlet on a PDU or a group of multiple outlets that are controlled in unison. It may also refer to a power metering device such as an ammeter that does not have control capabilities (on/off) and only has metering capabilities.
Triggers the event.

member.summary: Raised when the array returned by has changed.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerOverEthernetPort
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a power over ethernet port which supports PoE-specific features
This capability is not implemented on a top-level device and is instead implemented on an inside both and which also implements the capability to describe the port. A top-device which is only a network port does not really make any sense.
If the device only contains one network port, it should still implement and to hold that port rather than attempting to implement on the top-level device.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerOverEthernetPort.DeviceAttached
member.summary:
Reports whether or not a PoE device is attached to the port
Should report when no device is attached or a non-PoE device is attached. Applications must tolerate a driver which reports as well in the case of a non-PoE device as some drivers may not be able to tell the difference.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerOverEthernetPort.EffectivePowerAllocation
member.summary:
Reports the "effective" power allocated to this port in Watts.
Devices with multiple PoE ports often allocate a power budget to a port based on the detected . However, some devices also allow custom user-specified limits. This property reports whatever the active power allocation is, whether that be from auto-detection based on power class or from the user-specified limit.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.PowerManagement.IPowerOverEthernetPort.PowerClass
member.summary:
The PoE Power Class of the device attached to this port
A null value indicates that the class is unknown, either because it is uninitialized, unsupported, no device is connected, the connected device is not a PoE device, or PoE power class detection is otherwise unavailable.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable
member.summary:
Interface to be implemented by a device which supports being controlled via voice using data from the proprietary TSR remote data format
This proprietary format includes a header followed by a "Code 0" Opus packet as described in Section 3.2.2 of RFC 6716 (https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6716#section-3.2.2). "Code 0" indicates the packet contains only a single frame of data.
The header consists of a start byte, where bits 0-4 provide the header length (where that length includes the first byte in its count) followed by the additional data bytes indicated by that length.
member.remarks: See for more information about device capabilities.

member.name: P:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable.ReadyToBeginVoiceSession
member.summary:
Indicates whether the device is ready to begin a new voice session and may be called. Will be false during an active voice session (between calls to and ).
Note that this does NOT preclude status provided by other capabilities such as . When is false, the value of should not be read or trusted.

member.name: E:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable.ReadyToBeginVoiceSessionChanged
member.summary: Raised when the property has changed

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable.BeginVoiceSession
member.summary:
Begins a voice command session with the device
MUST be called prior to calling . This informs the device that voice data is coming and to begin a session where it will take the samples to buffer and/or parse.
If beginning the session is successful, will be set to false and remain false until is called. Applications do NOT need to wait for to go false before calling after calling . Drivers must expect to buffer incoming voice data as necessary in order to send to the device.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable.EndVoiceSession
member.summary:
Closes an existing voice session with the device
This typically signals the device to take the action that it parsed out of the samples sent via between and .
Once the session is complete, will typically be set to true again, unless there is some other reason that it is not ready to begin a new session.

member.name: M:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Capabilities.VoiceControl.ITsrVoiceControllable.SendVoiceData(System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Sends voice data to the Device in the proprietary TSR voice format.
This should only be called between calls of and to begin and end the voice session, respectively.
member.param: Bytes of voice data including the TSR header and Opus packet
member.remarks: See the documentation for for more information on the format of this audio data.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.Collections.ImmutableArray`1
member.summary:
An array that cannot change size or contents once it is constructed. It is recommended that items in the array are also immutable.
To encourage object reuse, this can only be constructed using the static methods
This is a thread-safe alternative to .NET's . That name is misleading because it is just a wrapper to the real collection. The original collection may still change.
However, the above statements do not mean everything should be an immutable array, but it is always something to consider. Typically, this should be used on public collections that have a corresponding "changed" event. If the collection is guaranteed to never change after construction, then you can use the aforementioned read-only collection.
This also may be used on public interfaces that potentially untrusted developers will be implementing. This would prevent them from changing the collection after they construct it.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.IDeviceCapability
member.summary:
Base interface used to identify a capability as a Device capability.
All device capability events may occur asynchronously (after a method or property setter returns). They may also occur synchronously (during a method or property setter).
Unless otherwise noted, all properties, methods and events are not available for use until the implementing device driver indicates it is either online or if available, a "ready" flag on a specific capability indicating commands can now be executed. In other words, until the device is online or ready, properties will be at their default values, methods will do nothing and no events will be raised.
Unsupported properties, methods and events should never be accessed if that device capability interface indicates that they are unsupported as they may throw exceptions.
All device drivers and their capability implementations must be thread-safe.
Regarding collections and lists, most device capabilities will return an and provide a corresponding event with arguments of type . Drivers should always return a read-only copy of their list or use a "yield return" statement to avoid having their internal collections accidentally modified. Consumers of the device capability should retrieve the enumerable once and make their own copy of the list. Based on the arguments of the list changed event, the consumers can then update their copy of the list without asking this device for the full list again (unless the event was a ; In that case, the full list would need to be retrieved again anyway).
Regarding callback methods, some device capabilities contain methods which allow a callback method to be specified. Most device operations are "fire and forget", and based on feedback and error reporting capabilities, it can be determined if a device is in a failed state. However, in certain cases a more contextual response is required, such as when configuring a device or making requests that involve external services that may result in an external error occurring, rather than the device itself entering an error state. That is when capabilities will provide callback methods for specific operations. Keep in mind, callback methods are never guaranteed to be called on the same thread on which the original method call was executed.
For convenience, this framework also provides some base implementations for interfaces that describe an immutable object. However, for interfaces that contain values that may change, no base implementation is provided because the threading model and other aspects of the implementing driver are not known. Therefore, it is likely raising events from the base class would cause unknown problems and possibly deadlock.

member.name: T:Crestron.DeviceDrivers.API.IDeviceWithCapabilities
member.summary:
Interface that must be implemented by a device driver.
All device capabilities on a device must be retrievable at the time the driver is constructed. However, as documented by , the actual supported flags and the rest of the interface do not have to be accessible until the device is "ready" as indicated by the capability.

member.summary:
Retrieves the specified device capability if this device supports it.
For more details about device capabilities, see and .
member.returns: An implementation of the capability, or null if the capability is not supported.

member.summary:
Checks if the current logging level will allow a log entry at the specified to be logged.
This method should be used to prevent unnecessary execution of logging code that requires computations in the message arguments, passing of value types (because they will be boxed) or a loop that does nothing but log information.
